required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Patient Reported Outcomes for Bladder Management Strategies in Spinal Cord Injury
clinical_study.official_title: Patient Reported Outcomes for Bladder Management Strategies in Spinal Cord Injury

brief_summary.textblock: The investigators goal is to create a better understanding of patient reported outcomes for bladder management strategies (clean intermittent catheterization (CIC), indwelling catheter (IDC) and bladder surgery.

detailed_description.textblock: Our study is a longitudinal observational study between bladder management strategies, comparing outcomes measured by patient reported questionnaires.

primary_outcome.measure: Neurogenic Bladder Symptom Score (NBSS): comparing change in: CIC, IDC, Voiding, and Surgery
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 1 year longitudinal follow up

primary_outcome.measure: The Spinal Cord Injury Quality of Life Measurement System Bladder Management Difficulties (SCI-QOL Difficulties): comparing change in: CIC, IDC, Voiding, and Surgery
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 1 year longitudinal follow up
primary_outcome.description: The SCI-QoL Difficulties assesses feelings and psychosocial impact of bladder symptoms

primary_outcome.measure: The Spinal Cord Injury Quality of Life Measurement System Bladder Complications (SCI-QOL Complications): comparing change in: CIC, IDC, Voiding, and Surgery
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 1 year longitudinal follow up
primary_outcome.description: The SCI-QoL Complications assesses degree of bladder complications their psychosocial impact

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 1 year longitudinal follow up
secondary_outcome.description: The Incontinence subdomain measures degree of incontinence

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 1 year longitudinal follow up
secondary_outcome.description: The Storage and Voiding subdomain measures symptoms related to frequency and emptying of the bladder

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 1 year longitudinal follow up
secondary_outcome.description: The Consequences subdomain measures bladder related complications

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 1 year longitudinal follow up
secondary_outcome.description: The final question of the NBSS assesses overall satisfaction with the urinary system

arm_group.description: Participants performing intermittent catheterization of their bladder, having not had augmentation cystoplasty or creation of a catheterizable channel
Participants utilizing an Foley catheter or a suprapubic tube (cystostomy)

Undergoing any of the following surgeries: augmentation cystoplasty with or without a catheterizable channel, creation of catheterizable channel alone, urinary diversion (conduit or continent catheterizable pouch)
Participants with volitional control, voiding into diapers or a condom catheter via crede, valsalva, or spontaneous leakage

intervention.description: Clean intermittent self catheterization is a standard of care.
Indwelling catheterization is a standard of care.
Bladder surgery is a standard of care.
Voiding spontaneously is a standard of care.

study_pop.textblock: Participants with neurogenic bladder with urinary issues and currently being managed by one/ any of various bladder management treatments (clean intermittent catheterization, indwelling catheter, voiding or bladder surgery).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Participants with acquired spinal cord injury
- Participants with neurogenic bladder
- Participants must be undergoing or starting at least one of the following bladder management treatments at the time of enrollment. a) Clean intermittent catheterization (CIC) b) Have an indwelling catheter (IDC) c) Spontaneous voiding, and d) Have undergone bladder surgery
- Age 18 or older
- Willingness and ability to comply with study engagement
- Able to provide consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Degenerative spinal cord issues, such as multiple sclerosis, neuromuscular dysfunction
- Congenital spinal cord issues, such as spina bifida, myelomeningocele, or cerebral palsy
- Participants that belong to a vulnerable population (pregnant, prisoners, mentally handicapped, etc)
- Participants less than 18 years of age

overall_official.affiliation: University of Utah School of Medicine - Urology

results_reference.citation: Patel DP, Lenherr SM, Stoffel JT, Elliott SP, Welk B, Presson AP, Jha A, Rosenbluth J, Myers JB; Neurogenic Bladder Research Group. Study protocol: patient reported outcomes for bladder management strategies in spinal cord injury. BMC Urol. 2017 Oct 10;17(1):95. doi: 10.1186/s12894-017-0286-3.

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan
